nodes.bodyText:
What's the performance difference (rough numbers are enough) in the following scenario compared to original impl

single process Fuse read with NaiveSharedGrpcDataReader
Single process Fuse read without NaiveSharedGrpcDataReader
Multiple (four) processes Fuse read with NaiveSharedGrpcDataReader
Multiple (four) processes Fuse read without NaiveSharedGrpcDataReader

Just have some rough number:

Single process fuse read
NaivceDataReader -> 11s
GrpcDataReader -> 18 ~ 20 s
4 processes
NaiveDataReader -> 20s
GrpcDataReader -> 500 ~ 600 s, 1600s in worst case

By the way, if with code change in BlockInStream.seek + GrpcDataReader, single process perf is 20s, and 4 process read perf is 140 ~ 150s
Change to NaiveCachedGrpcDataReader then will be easier to debug
Why remove the part for GrpcDataMessagingBlockingStream?

GrpcDataMessagingBlockingStream can't be used here.
DataBuffer.getReadOnlyByteBuffer is used to clone a copy in SharedDataReader.readChunk. getReadOnlyByteBuffer is not implemented in DataBuffer returned from GrpcDataMessagingBlockingStream.
if the client's buffer is full?

Will we add a mechanism to limit the available buffer used for the NaiveReader and make the available buffer configurable? Can be done in future PRs.
Kind of worry about the data reader introduces the client-side OOM issue.
if index < mBufferCount, no need to lock?
Good point, that could save some runtime
isn't this case (pos < mLength) given? since we asserted pos <= mLength and return on pos == mLength

'else' part is for (pos == mLength).  CloseDataReader() is mandatory in this case.
And 'return' is on pos == mPos but not pos == mLength.
Make sense, changed to else{} directly and remove the original else{} block.

let's avoid throwing exceptions in a constructor. If this is required, create a static factory method to create an instance which may throw exceptions rather than having it in constructor. Constructor should be lightweight and no requirement to cover its failure case
Move the logics to Factory, please take a look

same comments on constructor vs factory method as NaiveCachedGrpcDataReader.
Since this is private and only invoked by Factory.create, we should avoid throwing Exceptions here, and you can move the part of code that may throw exception to the factory method
Moved the logics to Factory, please take a look

is mBlockReaders the only data structure to protect by this lock?
to q2, yes, it's the only resource protected by this lock

Added
Yeah, it mainly use for BlockReaders, didn't find other data structures fully protected by this lock
can we move this outside of critical session?
Done
I actually think this part of looking up and returning cached reader should go to factory rather than constructor here
That's a better option.
Moved
Considering Closer?
I think this is a redundant case. please check
Removed this block, think it's abundant as well

nodes.bodyText: For mDataBuffers, only the update (write buff) is guarded by the mBufferLocks, all other read operations are not protected.
any reason to use volatile int rather than AtomicInteger?

Volatile and AtomicInteger don't make a difference here.  AtomicInteger internally uses volatile for the integer value. AtomicInteger mainly improved for setting values. in our case, we only increase the value under a write lock.
Changed the volatile to AtomicInteger
any reason to have this registration here rather than in constructor or factory method?
Moved to the constructor, thanks!

Nit: I would prefer to put the creation of closer and dataBuffers inside the constructor rather than in factory method here. It is easier to reason the ownership of these data structures in that way. In contrast, the creation of stream , client is not guaranteed to succeed with exception possibly thrown, thus why we should leave it in factory method and pass them to constructor as param on successful creation.
As long as the constructor is ensured to complete, we should be good.
Make sense. Moved the closer and DataBuffer[] related logics back to the constructor. The Closer in the constructor is better to show the ownership.

I would call this BufferCachingGrpcDataReader
my personal preference: do not to use final when defining a class  unless you are very sure no one should extend it
Better to extend DataReader unless there is particular reason

Removed

Done

Regarding lock , Check my next comment on lock striping first.  AgainmCachedDataReader.close() may take a long time, we should not put this inside a critical session by a global lock.
After lock striping, we can remove reader from the BLOCK_READERS map if its refcount reaches 0, but calling  mCachedDataReader.close() outside the lock to further make sure operations inside the lock is minimal.

currently this is not specific to fuse. we can either make it only works on fuse (e.g., check process type), or rename the flag to make it usable in general.
FUSE_SHARED_GRPC_DATA_READER_ENABLED

I think it's specific to FUSE use case, not sure if it's able to work on other cases.
The bufferCachingDataReader is more general, but the SharedDataReader can be only used for fuse since it is based on the assumption
 * It follows GrpcDataReader protocol and takes strong assumption:
 * Parallel read to the same file happens on the same time, so that read request is
 * serialized by kernel

it relies on one thread do seek() and then readChunk()  and then the other thread do seek() -> readChunk()s.
Maybe we can change the current name SharedDataReader to FuseSharedDataReader to be more clear?
I would simply call this class SharedGrpcDataReader
Changed to SharedGrpcDataReader
The try to read data already received but haven't processed logic works for both flag is off and on.  Will change the instanceof to a flag check.
Changed to if (mContext.getClusterConf().getBoolean(PropertyKey.FUSE_SHARED_CACHING_READER_ENABLED)) {
@LuQQiu this else branch is still not guarded and will still be accessible even the flag is off, right?

Yeah, the change can be applied to all cases, not only related to sharedDataReader.
Do we want to be safe and put it under the flag for now and maybe add a TODO(lu) to move it not guarded in the future?

yes let's put all the new logic in BlockInStream protected by the flag and leave a TODO.
Thanks
nit: unnecessary empty lines at line 88 and 95. The code base should be compact for readability in general.
Removed, thanks
@Nullable
Done

a few questions on reclaiming resources:

if mClient is closed, do we still need to close mStream, and vise versa
what should be the order to close mStream and mClient?
Changed back to the original close way to guarantee the order
marking @Nullablewhenever it is possible. IDE will help a lot to warn null check in invokers.
Added, thanks! Will remember adding Nullable
Changed, thanks
return refcount incremented? kinda confusing to say the current count.
Changed, thanks

final.
mark member variables final whenever possible.
Marked, thanks!
do we need to close stream here too?

Add the stream close here,
I am little worry about when creating the stream, errors thrown, but i guess can still do the close() since it checks isOpen first.

I don't think we need another flag FUSE_SHARED_CACHING_READER_LOCKS on this.
Picking a constant number like 32 is good enough to ensure ~32 concurrent readers.
In general, we should be very conservative in adding new configuration flags.
Unless we're very sure users will tune it.
Yeah, it may not be helpful and necessary to add it as a property, removed

let's make a static util method to return the corresponding lock in the lock array based on block Id.
e.g.,
private static ReentrantReadWriteLock getBlockLock(long blockId) {
  return BLOCK_LOCKS[(int) (blockId % BLOCK_LOCKS.length)]
}

Then in both close and create, let's all use the util method rather than hardcode the same logic twice.
In case we change the logic in the future, we only need to go one place
Changed, thanks
Done thanks

This check is not complete. Even the config is true, usual GrpcDataReader will still be used if block size is <= 4 * chunksize.
Would recommend to keep the logic of checking class of the instance. The logic inner if block is only applicable to cached data reader.
Oh good catch!! Will change back to instanceof
mMarshaller could be removed since it's not used in this class.
Changed, thanks!
